thread.title: 2 scheduled to stand trial in Bartmess murder
thread.title_full: 2 scheduled to stand trial in Bartmess murder - The Denver Post

author: Dana Rieck
title: 2 scheduled to stand trial in Bartmess murder
text:
Not quite a year after Andrea Bartmess' body was found near Red Feather Lakes Road , three people have pleaded guilty to charges related to her homicide and two others are preparing to stand trial for capital murder charges.
Those five people were arrested and charged in Bartmess' killing within two weeks of her body being found on Nov. 21, 2014: Michael Bensen, 46, of Fort Collins; Patrick Hannon, 52, of Fort Collins; Chataigner McCaffrey-Pickett, 22, of Fort Collins; Jose Rosario, 36, of Fort Collins; and Kimberly Guinn, 33, of Loveland.
Bensen is facing two counts of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit first-degree murder, first-degree kidnapping, second-degree kidnapping and unlawful sexual contact. He pleaded not guilty. A 10-day trial is scheduled for Nov. 30 at 9 a.m.
Hannon is also facing two counts of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit first-degree murder, first-degree kidnapping, second-degree kidnapping, unlawful sexual contact and another charge alleging sexual assault. He pleaded not guilty and will stand trial for 10 days on Feb. 22, 2016 at 9 a.m.
Advertisement According to information from the District Attorney's Office, McCaffrey-Pickett pleaded guilty to first-degree assault with a deadly weapon — she appears again in court Friday. Before her plea, McCaffrey-Pickett was facing first-degree murder, second-degree kidnapping and conspiracy to commit murder, all felony charges.
Rosario pleaded guilty to second-degree murder, according to the District Attorney's Office. He originally faced two counts of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit first-degree murder, first-degree kidnapping and second-degree kidnapping. He will appear in court Jan. 20, 2016.
The last suspect in the case, Guinn, also pleaded guilty. She will appear in court again Dec. 18 on a first-degree kidnapping charge. She, too, originally faced charges of two counts of first-degree murder, conspiracy to commit murder in the first degree, first-degree kidnapping and second-degree kidnapping before the plea.
The details of the homicide case were made public for the first time in an April preliminary hearing regarding Bensen's charges . It was reported there that Bartmess' autopsy determined she had died from hypothermia, multiple blunt force trauma to her head and a laceration to her neck
Prosecutors laid out evidence alleging the five co-defendants conspired to kidnap, beat and kill Bartmess in early October 2014 — they said Bensen admitted to "finishing the job" when he drove her out on Red Feather Lakes Road about 9.5 miles west of U.S. 287 to kill her and dump her body.
While Bartmess was last known to be living in Fort Collins, her mother Wilma Cotten said she had spent some time in Loveland prior. Bartmess had lived with her in Aurora until Easter 2014.
"Andrea was a very energetic, outgoing, fun-loving kid who wanted everyone to like her," Cotten said in November 2014. "But she had a dark side; she suffered with bipolar (disorder). We struggled to find the right combination of therapy and medications for her."
Dana Rieck: 970-635-3630, rieckd@reporter-herald.com or twitter.com/DanaRieckRH
